awd_titl_txt: Support for Young Investigator Participation at the 8th International Conference on Flood Management (ICFM8), Iowa City, August 17-19, 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
The Eighth International Conference on Flood Management (ICFM8) is a flood-focused international event attracting academic scientists, researchers, practitioners, educators, and public officials involved in flood mitigation. The conference is to be held in Iowa City, August 17-19, 2020. U.S. participants will present their cutting-edge research, and also learn from international leaders in specific knowledge areas and begin dialogue necessary to produce actionable science for flood mitigation and increased resilience. ICFM8 will likely attract about 400 participants, including record numbers of young scientists and practitioners who will confront flooding's continuously expanding socio-economic threat. Key outcomes of the conference will include guidance on flood hazards, mitigation solutions based on "natural" and man-made approaches, and identification of opportunities associated with the deployment of distributed research programs to generate the knowledge, data, and models for improved flood prediction, mitigation, and increased community resilience. 

The majority of NSF funds will support participation at the conference for U.S.-based graduate students and young professionals (i.e., postdoctoral scholars), with strong preference for underrepresented minorities. The number of participants to be supported is an estimated 15 traveling students and 35 local students. Bringing more graduate students and young investigators to ICFM8 will allow them to network with peers and future employers and to learn about available careers. A key impact of this conference will be the high level of knowledge transfer and dissemination accomplished during the event and into the future. Participating students and young investigators will gain enhanced scientific and educational benefits through their attendance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Iowa Young Professional Workshop (YPW) has offered unique, first-hand professional training activities and networking opportunities. The main outcome of this project is the successful engagement of the workshop participants in lively discussions/debates on emerging trends in flood mitigation and creating a stimulative environment for developing networks based on research interests.

The initial YPW was organized around the 8th International Conference for Flood Management (ICFM8) planned to be delivered in person on August 17-19, at the University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. in the preparation stage of the iCFM8, we attained a record-breaking number of conference contributors from a large number of countries. The unfortunate circumstances created by the Covid pandemic have narrowed the original dissemination plan to only in-person interactions with the Iowa Flood Center researchers at the University of Iowa, the main local organizer of the conference. The participation of the Iowa Flood Center?s junior and senior researchers to the oral presentation session and the open forum has exposed the young investigators to a broad range of first-hand experiences regarding generating knowledge, data, and models for improving flood prediction, mitigation and increased community resilience to floods. 

With respect to content, the YPW was delivered as originally planned, with the exception that the audience was dramatically reduced and limited to United States participants. Due to various circumstances occuring in the two years of delay (e.g., change of status in the affiliations, other personal changes, Covid threat, and anomalies in aerian traffic), the initial number of 30 US Young Professional participants awarded with full or partial NSF support has continuously reduced as the new YPW delivery date was approaching. Eventually, the YPW, organized on August 8-10 2022, entailed 17 out-of campus participants (3 young career faculty, 4 postd-octoral researchers, 7 PhD and 2 Masters candidates, and 1 engineer in training). The out-of-campus presenters were accompanied by 20 graduate students and 10 junior and
senior researchers affiliated with the Iowa Flood Center, The University of Iowa. Given all the adverse circumstances, we consider that the YPW was a memorable professional experience for both the out-of-campus and local workshop participants.

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2022
Modified by: Marian Muste
